description: Inherited from Middle English spurge, from Old French espurge, from espurgier (“to purge”), from Latin expurgo (“I purge”); the bitter milky sap of these plants was formerly used as a purgative.

entries.meaning: Any plant of the genus Euphorbia, a diverse genus of over 2,000 species.
examples: But cockle, spurge, according to their law / Might propagate their kind, with none to awe, / You'd think; a burr had been a treasure trove.

verbs.description: spurge (third-person singular simple present spurges, present participle spurging, simple past and past participle spurged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To emit foam; to froth; said of the emission of yeast from beer during fermentation.
examples: The body's somthing noysome: 'tis a stale one; / Good troth it spurgeth very monstrously.
